awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Combining Traditional Building Inspection Sensors with Deep Learning and Robotics
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to improve buildings envelopes that exacerbate greenhouse gas emissions and cause quality of life problems. The technology seeks to provide a non-invasive, integrated solution to locate and document moisture intrusion, thermal bridges, and air leaks to diagnose building envelope issues. The system identifies and quantifies common envelope defects and applies long-wave radar and deep learning to detect hidden deep moisture penetration and other major envelope defects. With this system, it is possible to perform low-cost, targeted micro-retrofits to address envelope issues. This project has the potential to (1) increase the efficiency and detection abilities of building health monitoring techniques; (2) increase the resilience of built infrastructure through comprehensive asset management and preventative building maintenance owing to improved early detection capabilities; (3) enable a strong cross collaboration across local government, industry, non-profits, and academia.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a non-invasive, integrated solution to locate and document moisture intrusion, thermal bridges, and air leaks in buildings. The system identifies and quantifies common envelope defects and applies long-wave radar and deep learning to detect hidden deep moisture penetration and other major envelope defects. Once identified, it may be possible to perform low-cost, targeted micro-retrofits to address the envelope issues. This project is a amalgamation of a number of complementary technologies that have the potential to significantly improve the field of building health monitoring.  Project outcomes may enhance the ability to solve current building envelope inspections problems, increase the resilience of widely-used aging commercial and residential infrastructures, and provide a foundation for further study of non-destructive testing on building envelopes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report for the NSF I-Corps Project (NSF #2232494)

This NSF I-Corps project focused on creating an innovative, non-invasive system for identifying and addressing critical issues in building envelopes, such as moisture intrusion, thermal bridges, and air leaks. These problems reduce energy efficiency, contribute to greenhouse gas emissions, and negatively impact quality of life. Our project successfully demonstrated a system that combines long-wave radar imaging with deep learning to detect and document building envelope defects, enabling cost-effective, targeted micro-retrofits.

Intellectual Merit

We advanced the field of building health monitoring through novel integration of long-wave radar and artificial intelligence. This approach enabled precise detection of hidden moisture penetration and thermal anomalies in building structures. The system also quantifies the severity of defects, making it more effective than conventional diagnostic methods. Key achievements included refining radar signal interpretation and optimizing deep learning models for defect detection. Our work lays a solid foundation for advancing non-destructive testing techniques in the building industry.

Broader Impacts

The project addresses critical challenges in energy conservation, infrastructure resilience, and community well-being. By enabling targeted retrofits, the system reduces energy waste and greenhouse gas emissions, contributing to global sustainability goals. Additionally, it enhances infrastructure durability through early detection of building envelope issues, benefiting aging commercial and residential structures, particularly in underserved communities.

Collaboration was central to our approach. Partnerships with local governments, industry stakeholders, non-profits, and academic institutions ensured that the technology was aligned with real-world needs. These collaborations also facilitated knowledge sharing and capacity building, fostering an interdisciplinary effort to tackle pressing infrastructure challenges.

Notable Outcomes

  1. Pending Patent: Our innovation is protected under a pending patent titled SYSTEM AND METHOD FOR ROBOTIC INSPECTION (Patent No. US20240134007A1, UNITED STATES, https://patents.google.com/patent/US20240134007A1/), reflecting its uniqueness and commercial potential.
  2. Startup Formation: We established a startup, Building Diagnostic Robotics (https://www.buildingdiagnosticrobotics.com/), which has already commenced operations with a growing team, underscoring the market viability of our technology.
  3. Scientific Contributions: The project resulted in two publications presented at ISARC 2023, disseminating our findings to the international robotics and automation community.
  4. Technology Development and Validation: We successfully built and validated a prototype integrating long-wave radar, thermal imaging, and AI. Field tests demonstrated its high accuracy in identifying defects across diverse building types.
  5. Market Discovery: Customer discovery efforts revealed a strong market demand, guiding our commercialization strategy to address stakeholders in construction, facility management, and energy sectors.
  6. Workforce Development: Graduate students involved in the project gained interdisciplinary expertise, equipping them with valuable skills in radar imaging, AI, and building science.

In conclusion, this NSF I-Corps project has delivered significant advancements in building diagnostics, with substantial contributions to sustainability, infrastructure resilience, and industry innovation. These outcomes demonstrate the potential for long-term impact in addressing critical challenges in the built environment.

 


Last Modified: 12/02/2024
Modified by: Chen Feng
